title: Site of Primary Action
content: Where in the nephron does furosemide primarily exert its diuretic effect?
options: Proximal convoluted tubule
Ascending limb of the loop of Henle
Distal convoluted tubule
Collecting duct

title: Inhibited Ion Transporters
content: Which ion transporter is primarily inhibited by furosemide in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle?
options: Na+/K+ ATPase pump
NKCC2 (sodium-potassium-chloride cotransporter)
ROMK (Romanski potassium channel)
Cl-/HCO3- exchanger

title: Effect on Ion Excretion
content: What is the primary effect of furosemide's action on ion reabsorption in the ascending limb?
options: Decreases sodium, potassium, and chloride reabsorption
Increases sodium, potassium, and chloride reabsorption
Decreases sodium and potassium reabsorption, increases chloride reabsorption
Increases sodium reabsorption, decreases potassium and chloride

title: Consequence on Potassium Levels
content: How does furosemide's inhibition of ROMK in the distal convoluted tubule affect potassium excretion?
options: Increases potassium excretion
Decreases potassium excretion
No significant effect on potassium levels

title: Therapeutic Use and Mechanism
content: What is the primary therapeutic use of furosemide due to its mechanism of action?
options: Reducing blood pressure by decreasing peripheral resistance
Increasing urine output by enhancing electrolyte excretion
Correcting metabolic acidosis by exchanging chloride for bicarbonate

title: Comparison with Thiazides
content: How does the site and mechanism of action of furosemide differ from that of thiazide diuretics?
options: Both act in the same part of the nephron but target different ion transporters
urosemide acts in the proximal tubule, while thiazides act in the loop of Henle
Thiazides inhibit NKCC2, whereas furosemide primarily inhibits ROMK
Furosemide acts in the loop of Henle and affects more ions than thiazides

title: Clinical Implication of Electrolyte Loss
content: What is a common electrolyte disturbance associated with the use of furosemide?
options: Hypokalemia
Hyperkalemia
Hyponatremia
Hypernatremia

title: Hydrostatic Oncomelanin Pathway
content: Which statement best describes the role of hydrostatic oncomelanin in furosemide's action?
options: It directly inhibits ROMK in the distal convoluted tubule
It enhances the effect of NKCC2 inhibition in the loop of Henle
It facilitates water reabsorption independently of sodium

title: Pharmacokinetics
content: What is the primary route of excretion for furosemide?
options: Renal
Hepatic
Biliary
Pulmonary

title: Tissue Selectivity
content: Why is furosemide considered to have greater tissue selectivity compared to other diuretics?
options: Due to its high extraction by the kidneys
Because it is metabolized in the liver
Its inability to cross the blood-brain barrier
